questions.text: A 56-year-old female who initially presented with symptoms like nausea and vomiting and features suggesting irritable bowel syndrome water later after a battery of investigations was diagnosed to have an ovarian tumor. On surgical staging of the tumor, the tumor was confined to both the ovaries with capsule intact. What will the FIGO staging of the tumor be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IB In the given question, for the staging of the ovarian tumor, the following pneumonic can be used to remember the staging while keeping the basic in mind that Stage I- confined to the organ Stage II- confined to nearby structures. Stage III- peritoneal involvement or outside pelvis Stage IV- distant metastasis. The mnemonic that is used is- ABC DUBMASH- for stage I Intra- stage II Extra-stage III Poda-stage IV According to ABC- as B stands for the involvement of B/L ovaries, hence the stage becomes IB.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - IA- defines the presence or involvement of a single ovary. (A From ABC DUBMASH) Option C - IC- defines the involvement of one or both ovaries with capsule rupture . (C from THE ABC DUBMASH where DU- represents stage IC1, B- IC2, and MAS- IC3) Option D - II- is for intrapelvic structures involvement.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female diagnosed with an endodermal sinus tumor undergoes its excision as the tumor was staged as IA on surgical staging followed which she was also given a chemotherapy regimen BEP. What does stage IA correspond to?

options.label: A
options.text: The tumor is confined to one ovary but with the capsule not intact.

options.label: B
options.text: The tumor is confined to two ovaries with the capsule intact.

options.label: C
options.text: Tumor confined to one ovary with capsule intact.

options.label: D
options.text: The tumor was confined to one ovary but there occurred a surgical spill during surgery.

questions.correct_answer: C. Tumor confined to one ovary with capsule intact.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tumor confined to one ovary with capsule intact. ABC DUBMASH- for stage I Intra- stage II Extra-stage III Poda-stage IV In this, A represents stage IA where the tumor is confined to one ovary.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Tumor confined to one ovary but with capsule not intact- represents stage IC (C from ABC DUBMASH represents capsule rupture) Option B - Tumor confined to two ovaries with capsule intact- stage IB (b from ABC represents B/L ovarian involvement with capsule intact. Option D - Tumor confined to one ovary but there occurred surgical spill during surgery- stage IC1 (du -DUBMASH denotes stage IC1)

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman cachexic undergoes surgical staging of the tumor for ovarian tumor. After removal of the specimen, histopathological examination shows microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal deposits. What will be the staging of the tumor?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IIIA2 In the given question, as given, there is an extrapelvic peritoneal extension which is microscopic, hence in the given question using the mnemonic for the cancer staging. ABC DUBMASH- for stage I Intra- stage II Extra-stage III Poda-stage IV We can easily say that ‘extra’ denotes extrapelvic hence it is stage III. To further classify in stage III- IIIA1- indicates positive retroperitoneal lymph node only.(option A) IIIA2- indicates microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal involvement. IIIB- indicates macroscopic extrapelvic peritoneal involvement. Stage IV is represented by ‘PoDa’ according to the mnemonic- Stage IVA- positive pleural cytology. (‘Po). Stage IVB- Distant metastasis to other organs like the liver, and spleen. (Da). Other options are not appropriate.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female was operated on for an ovarian tumor. The tumor was limited to one ovary with the capsule intact before the surgery. However, during the surgery, the capsule got accidentally ruptured, and a surgical spill occurred. According to the given situation, what will be the stage of the tumor now?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IC1 In the given clinical question, the female initially had stage IA and as the surgical spill occurred during the surgery, it represents stage IC1 . This can be easily remembered by Mnemonic- ABC DUBMASH- for stage I A- IA for the involvement of U/L ovary with capsule intact. B- IB for the involvement of B/L ovary with capsule intact. C- Involvement of one or both ovaries with capsule rupture Du-IC1- surgical spill/ during surgery. B-IC2- capsule rupture before the surgery.(option D) MAS-IC3- Malignant cells in the Ascites or peritoneal washings.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and D are not appropriate options.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented with features like abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting from the past 2 months. She gives a history of ovarian cancer to her mother’s sister. She was evaluated for the same. The peritoneal washing taken was negative for the tumor cells but showed extension to the uterus. What will be the FIGO staging for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IIA In the given question, the tumor is extending intra-pelvic to the uterus only, hence it corresponds to Stage IIA of the tumor. According to the mnemonic used to remember the staging of ovarian tumors- Stage II corresponds to INTRA e. intrapelvic extension of the tumor. It is further divided into. IIA- extension or implantation on the uterus. IIB- extension to other intraperitoneal tissues.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - IC3 corresponds to malignant cells in the Ascitic fluid or peritoneal washings (as remembered by MAS from the part DUBMASH). Option C - IIB- extension to other intraperitoneal tissues. Option D - IIIA1- positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female in a debilitated, cachexia state and mass in the right adnexa with a family history of pancreatic carcinoma in her father cannot afford the treatment for her. There are gross ascites seen, with palpable inguinal lymph node. Which stage corresponds to inguinal lymph node involvement?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IVB In the given clinical scenario, the female is most probably suffering from ovarian malignancy as indicated by a debilitated, cachexia state and also right adnexal mass. She also has a family history of pancreatic carcinoma which points towards BRCA tumors. Inguinal lymph node involvement corresponds to stage IVB It can be easily learned by the mnemonic: ABC DUBMASH- for stage I Intra- stage II Extra-stage III Poda-stage IV Stage IV is represented by ‘PoDa’ according to the mnemonic- Stage IVA- positive pleural cytology. (‘Po). Stage IVB- Distant metastasis to other organs like the liver, and spleen.(Da) also, inguinal lymph node involvement is also included in this. Other options are not appropriate.

questions.text: You are operating on a 64-year-old female patient who presented with nonspecific symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Later her symptoms become more pronounced and the presence of dull aching pain and enlargement of the mass in the hypogastrium with abdominal distension. On surgical staging of the tumor, positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes were seen which were 6 mm in size. Which of the following is correct regarding the stage of this tumor?

options.label: A
options.text: The stage is IIIA1 for all tumors with positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only of size >=5 mm

options.label: B
options.text: The stage is IIIB for all tumors with positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only of size >=5 mm

options.label: C
options.text: The stage is IIIA1 for all tumors with positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only of size <=10 mm

options.label: D
options.text: The stage is IIIB for all tumors with positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only of size <=10 mm

questions.correct_answer: C. The stage is IIIA1 for all tumors with positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only of size <=10 mm
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The stage is IIIA1 for all tumors with positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only of size <=10 mm In the given clinical scenario, the retroperitoneal lymph nodes are positive with a size of 6mm in size. Hence, this corresponds to stage IIIA1 which is indicated by positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only of size <=10 mm. Stage III, according to the given mnemonic , corresponds to ‘EXTRA’ e. extrapelvic extension and/or metastasis to retroperitoneal lymph nodes . Other options are incorrect.
